expanded_description: Position, displacement, and distance are three fundamental concepts for describing where objects are and how far they move. Though related, they are distinct quantities with different meanings and uses in kinematics.

core_concept.principle: Position specifies where an object is located. Displacement measures the change in position (straight-line from start to finish). Distance measures the total path length traveled. Position and displacement are vectors; distance is a scalar.
core_concept.explanation: These three quantities answer different questions about motion. Position answers 'where is it?' Displacement answers 'how far and which way from start to finish?' Distance answers 'how far did it travel along its path?' Understanding the distinctions is crucial: an object that travels in a circle and returns to its starting point has traveled a distance equal to the circle's circumference, but has zero displacement. Position and displacement use + and - signs to indicate direction; distance is always positive.

image.caption: Position (location), displacement (straight-line change), and distance (path length) are distinct quantities

sections.introduction: Position is the most fundamental quantity in kinematics—it tells us exactly where an object is located at a specific moment in time.

key_concept.definition: Position is the location of an object relative to a chosen origin, specified by coordinates in a reference frame. In one-dimensional motion, position is a single coordinate (usually x or y) with a sign indicating direction from the origin.
key_concept.context: Position is a vector quantity—it has both magnitude (distance from origin) and direction (which side of origin). In 1D motion, direction is indicated by + or - sign. Position changes over time when an object moves.

principles.statement: Position is meaningless without specifying the reference point (origin) and coordinate system.
principles.application: Always establish origin and positive direction before stating positions.
principles.example: Saying 'the car is at position 50 m' is incomplete. Complete statement: 'With origin at the starting line and positive direction eastward, the car is at position $x = +50\ \text{m}$.' This means 50 m east of the starting line.

principles.statement: An object's position can change over time. Position at specific moments is written as $x(t)$ or 'x at time t.'
principles.application: Track how position changes to describe motion.
principles.example: At $t = 0\ \text{s}$, $x = 0\ \text{m}$ (starting position). At $t = 2\ \text{s}$, $x = 20\ \text{m}$ (moved to new position). At $t = 5\ \text{s}$, $x = 50\ \text{m}$ (continued moving).

principles.statement: In 1D motion, positive position means the object is on the positive side of the origin; negative position means negative side.
principles.application: Use + and - consistently with your chosen reference frame.
principles.example: If right is positive: $x = +10\ \text{m}$ means 10 m to the right of origin. $x = -5\ \text{m}$ means 5 m to the left of origin. $x = 0\ \text{m}$ means at the origin.

principles.statement: Unlike distance (always positive), position can be positive, negative, or zero.
principles.application: Negative position doesn't mean negative distance—it means position in the negative direction.
principles.example: $x = -20\ \text{m}$ means the object is 20 m in the negative direction (e.g., 20 m to the left if right is positive), NOT that it's somehow 'less than nothing.'

classifications.value: Symbols and conventions for representing position

examples.explanation: Position as function of time. $x(2)$ means position at $t = 2\ \text{s}$.
Initial position (at $t = 0$ or start of observation). Subscript 0 or i for 'initial.'
Final position (at end of observation). Subscript f for 'final.'
Positions at different specific times or of different objects.

classifications.behavior: Visual aids help understand position relationships.

examples.explanation: Horizontal line with origin (0) marked, positive direction (arrow), scale marks. Object's position shown by point or symbol on line.
Vertical axis = position, horizontal axis = time. Point on graph shows position at specific time. Graph shows how position changes.

worked_examples.title: Specifying Position
worked_examples.problem: A coordinate system has origin at point O, with positive direction to the right. Object A is 15 m to the right of O. Object B is 8 m to the left of O. Object C is at O. State the position of each object.

step_by_step.explanation: 15 m to the right, and right is positive direction
8 m to the left, and left is negative direction (opposite of positive right)
At origin O, where position = 0

worked_examples.concept_applied: Position uses + or - to indicate which side of origin. Positive direction is to the right, so right positions are +, left positions are -.

worked_examples.title: Position Change Over Time
worked_examples.problem: A car starts at position $x = 0\ \text{m}$ at $t = 0\ \text{s}$. At $t = 2\ \text{s}$, its position is $x = 30\ \text{m}$. At $t = 4\ \text{s}$, its position is $x = 60\ \text{m}$. Describe the car's motion.

step_by_step.explanation: $t = 0$: $x = 0\ \text{m}$. $t = 2\ \text{s}$: $x = 30\ \text{m}$. $t = 4\ \text{s}$: $x = 60\ \text{m}$. All positions positive.
From $t = 0$ to $t = 2$: $\Delta x = 30 - 0 = 30\ \text{m}$. From $t = 2$ to $t = 4$: $\Delta x = 60 - 30 = 30\ \text{m}$.
Position increasing steadily (moving in positive direction). Equal position changes in equal times (uniform motion).

worked_examples.final_answer: The car is moving in the positive direction at constant velocity. It covers 30 m every 2 seconds.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Tracking position over time reveals the character of motion. Steadily increasing position = motion in positive direction.

image.caption: Position on a coordinate line: origin at 0, positive direction indicated, positions shown with + or - coordinates

sections.introduction: Displacement measures the change in position—it tells us how far and in what direction an object has moved from its starting point.

key_concept.definition: Displacement is the change in position: the straight-line distance and direction from initial position to final position. Mathematically: $\Delta x = x_f - x_i$ (displacement equals final position minus initial position).
key_concept.context: Displacement is a vector quantity with magnitude and direction. The Greek letter $\Delta$ (delta) means 'change in.' Displacement depends only on starting and ending positions, not on the path taken between them.

principles.statement: The displacement formula $\Delta x = x_f - x_i$ gives both magnitude and direction of overall movement.
principles.application: Subtract positions to find displacement. Sign of result indicates direction.
principles.example: Start at $x_i = 5\ \text{m}$, end at $x_f = 20\ \text{m}$. $\Delta x = 20 - 5 = +15\ \text{m}$ (moved 15 m in positive direction). Start at $x_i = 10\ \text{m}$, end at $x_f = 3\ \text{m}$. $\Delta x = 3 - 10 = -7\ \text{m}$ (moved 7 m in negative direction).

principles.statement: Only starting and ending positions matter. The actual route taken is irrelevant to displacement.
principles.application: Different paths between same points give same displacement.
principles.example: Walk straight from $x = 0$ to $x = 10\ \text{m}$: $\Delta x = +10\ \text{m}$. Walk from $x = 0$ to $x = 15\ \text{m}$, then back to $x = 10\ \text{m}$: still $\Delta x = 10 - 0 = +10\ \text{m}$. Same displacement despite different paths.

principles.principle: Displacement Can Be Positive, Negative, or Zero
principles.statement: Positive displacement: net movement in positive direction. Negative displacement: net movement in negative direction. Zero displacement: same starting and ending position.
principles.application: Sign tells direction of overall movement.
principles.example: $\Delta x = +25\ \text{m}$: moved 25 m in positive direction overall. $\Delta x = -10\ \text{m}$: moved 10 m in negative direction overall. $\Delta x = 0\ \text{m}$: ended where you started (like going around a track).

principles.statement: The magnitude (absolute value) of displacement can never exceed distance traveled. Usually displacement magnitude < distance.
principles.application: Displacement is the 'shortest path' measure; distance includes all twists and turns.
principles.example: Walk 30 m east then 20 m west: distance = 50 m, displacement = $+10\ \text{m}$ (10 m east net). $|\Delta x| = 10\ \text{m} < 50\ \text{m}$.

worked_examples.title: Calculating Displacement
worked_examples.problem: A runner starts at position $x = 50\ \text{m}$ and runs to position $x = 200\ \text{m}$. Find the displacement.

step_by_step.explanation: $\Delta x = x_f - x_i$
Displacement is $+150\ \text{m}$, meaning the runner moved 150 m in the positive direction from start to finish.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Displacement = final position - initial position. Positive result means net movement in positive direction.

worked_examples.title: Negative Displacement
worked_examples.problem: A car is at position $x = 80\ \text{m}$ at $t = 0\ \text{s}$. At $t = 5\ \text{s}$, it's at position $x = 30\ \text{m}$. Find the displacement.

step_by_step.explanation: $x_i = 80\ \text{m}$ (initial), $x_f = 30\ \text{m}$ (final)
$\Delta x = x_f - x_i = 30\ \text{m} - 80\ \text{m}$
Negative displacement means net movement in negative direction. The car moved 50 m in the negative direction (e.g., backward or to the left).

worked_examples.concept_applied: Negative displacement indicates movement in the negative direction. The car's final position is less than initial position.

worked_examples.title: Zero Displacement
worked_examples.problem: A person walks from $x = 0\ \text{m}$ to $x = 100\ \text{m}$, then back to $x = 0\ \text{m}$. Find the displacement.

step_by_step.explanation: Started at $x_i = 0\ \text{m}$, ended at $x_f = 0\ \text{m}$ (back to start)
$\Delta x = x_f - x_i = 0 - 0$
Zero displacement means ended at starting position. Even though the person walked 200 m total (100 m out + 100 m back), the net change in position is zero.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Displacement is zero when final position equals initial position, regardless of path taken. Displacement ≠ distance for this round trip.

worked_examples.title: Multiple Segments
worked_examples.problem: A ball rolls from $x = 10\ \text{m}$ to $x = 40\ \text{m}$, then continues to $x = 55\ \text{m}$. Find (a) displacement for first segment, (b) displacement for second segment, (c) total displacement.

step_by_step.explanation: Method 1: Add segment displacements: $\Delta x_{\text{total}} = \Delta x_1 + \Delta x_2 = 30 + 15 = +45\ \text{m}$
step_by_step.calculation: Method 2: Overall start to finish: $\Delta x_{\text{total}} = 55 - 10 = +45\ \text{m}$. Both methods agree ✓

worked_examples.concept_applied: Total displacement can be found by: (1) adding individual displacements, or (2) final position minus initial position of entire journey.

image.alt: Diagram showing initial position, final position, and displacement arrow between them
image.caption: Displacement: straight-line arrow from initial position to final position, regardless of actual path

sections.introduction: Distance measures the total length of the path traveled, regardless of direction. Unlike displacement, distance is always positive.

key_concept.definition: Distance is the total length of the path actually traveled by an object. It is a scalar quantity (magnitude only, no direction) and is always positive or zero.
key_concept.context: Distance accounts for every twist, turn, and reversal along the path. It answers 'how far did you travel?' not 'where did you end up?' Unlike displacement (which can cancel out for back-and-forth motion), distance always accumulates.

principles.statement: Distance is the sum of all path lengths, regardless of direction. It cannot be negative.
principles.application: Add up all segments of motion as positive values.
principles.example: Walk 20 m forward then 15 m backward: distance = 20 + 15 = 35 m (not 5 m). Both segments count toward total distance.

principles.statement: Different routes between the same two points have different distances.
principles.application: The actual path matters for distance (unlike displacement, where path doesn't matter).
principles.example: Straight path from A to B: 10 m. Curved path from A to B: 15 m. Different distances, same displacement (10 m from A to B).

principles.statement: Distance traveled is always greater than or equal to the magnitude of displacement. Only equal when motion is in straight line without reversing.
principles.application: Straight-line motion in one direction: distance = |displacement|. Any turning or backtracking: distance > |displacement|.
principles.example: Straight 50 m east: distance = 50 m, |displacement| = 50 m. Go 30 m east then 20 m west: distance = 50 m, |displacement| = 10 m.

principles.statement: Unlike displacement (which can cancel out), distance always adds up. You can't 'un-travel' distance.
principles.application: Every bit of motion contributes to total distance, even if you reverse direction.
principles.example: Return to your starting point: displacement = 0, but distance = entire trip length.

worked_examples.title: Straight-Line Distance
worked_examples.problem: A car drives from $x = 10\ \text{m}$ to $x = 60\ \text{m}$ in a straight line. Find (a) distance, (b) displacement.

step_by_step.explanation: Straight-line motion: distance = magnitude of position change = $|60 - 10| = 50\ \text{m}$
$\Delta x = x_f - x_i = 60 - 10 = +50\ \text{m}$
For straight-line motion without reversal: distance = |displacement|. Here: 50 m = 50 m ✓

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Distance = 50 m, (b) Displacement = +50 m. Equal magnitudes because motion is straight line in one direction.
worked_examples.concept_applied: When motion is straight-line in one direction only, distance equals the magnitude of displacement.

worked_examples.title: Distance with Direction Changes
worked_examples.problem: A person walks 30 m east, then 20 m west. Find (a) total distance, (b) displacement.

step_by_step.explanation: Let east = positive direction
Add all path lengths: 30 m + 20 m = 50 m
First segment: +30 m. Second segment: -20 m. Total: +30 + (-20) = +10 m
Distance (50 m) > |displacement| (10 m) because motion reversed direction.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Distance = 50 m, (b) Displacement = +10 m (10 m east). Distance > |displacement| due to direction change.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Distance adds all segments as positive. Displacement adds segments with direction (opposite directions subtract). Distance ≥ |displacement| always.

worked_examples.title: Round Trip
worked_examples.problem: A runner runs around a 400 m track and returns to the start. Find (a) distance, (b) displacement.

step_by_step.explanation: Complete lap around 400 m track
Started at position $x_i$, ended at same position $x_f = x_i$. $\Delta x = x_f - x_i = 0$
Traveled 400 m (distance) but ended where you started (zero displacement). Classic example where distance ≠ 0 but displacement = 0.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Distance = 400 m, (b) Displacement = 0 m. Round trip: distance > 0, displacement = 0.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Returning to starting point: distance = path length traveled, displacement = 0 (no net change in position).

worked_examples.title: Complex Path
worked_examples.problem: Starting from $x = 0$, a car drives to $x = 50\ \text{m}$, then to $x = 20\ \text{m}$, then to $x = 80\ \text{m}$. Find (a) distance, (b) displacement.

step_by_step.explanation: Segment 1: 0 → 50 m (50 m traveled). Segment 2: 50 → 20 m (30 m traveled backward). Segment 3: 20 → 80 m (60 m traveled).
Sum all segment lengths: 50 + 30 + 60
From initial $x = 0$ to final $x = 80$: $\Delta x = 80 - 0$
Distance (140 m) > |displacement| (80 m) because path included backtracking (segment 2).

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Distance = 140 m, (b) Displacement = +80 m. Distance much greater due to back-and-forth motion.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Distance sums all path segments. Displacement only cares about net position change from start to finish.

image.caption: Distance (red path) follows actual route. Displacement (blue arrow) is straight from start to finish.

sections.introduction: Understanding when distance and displacement are equal, and when they differ, is crucial for analyzing motion.

key_concept.definition: Distance and displacement are equal in magnitude only when motion is in a straight line without any reversal of direction. In all other cases, distance > |displacement|.
key_concept.context: This distinction is important in many situations. A commuter's daily displacement (home to work to home) is zero, but daily distance is twice the one-way distance. Understanding both quantities gives a complete picture of motion.

examples.explanation: Drives 80 km east without stopping or reversing. Distance = 80 km, displacement = +80 km east. Magnitudes equal.
Falls straight down 10 m. Distance = 10 m, displacement = -10 m (downward). Magnitudes equal.
Runs 100 m without turning around. Distance = 100 m, displacement = +100 m. Equal.

characteristics: Any path that isn't straight line in one direction

examples.explanation: Any trip that returns to start: distance = total path, displacement = 0. Distance > 0, |displacement| = 0.
Walk along curved sidewalk 50 m from point A to point B. If A and B are 30 m apart (straight line), distance = 50 m, |displacement| = 30 m.
Walk 40 m forward, 15 m back, 10 m forward. Distance = 65 m, displacement = +35 m. Distance > |displacement|.

worked_examples.title: Identifying When Quantities Differ
worked_examples.problem: For each scenario, state whether distance equals |displacement| or distance > |displacement|: (a) Ball thrown straight up and caught at same height, (b) Car drives 50 km north, (c) Person walks around a square block back to start.

step_by_step.explanation: Goes up then comes back down to same height. Returns to starting position.
step_by_step.calculation: Displacement = 0 (same start and end). Distance = 2 × height (up + down). Distance > |displacement|.

step_by_step.explanation: Straight line, one direction, no reversal.
step_by_step.calculation: Distance = 50 km. Displacement = 50 km north. Magnitudes equal. Distance = |displacement|.

step_by_step.explanation: Closed loop, returns to start.
step_by_step.calculation: Displacement = 0 (ended at start). Distance = perimeter of block. Distance > |displacement|.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Distance = |displacement| only for straight-line motion in one direction. Any reversal, curve, or return makes distance > |displacement|.

image.alt: Side-by-side examples showing when distance equals and when it exceeds displacement magnitude
image.caption: Left: Straight path, distance = |displacement|. Right: Path with turns, distance > |displacement|

sections.introduction: Position, displacement, and distance concepts appear in everyday situations and practical problem-solving.

categories.description: GPS and mapping use these concepts.

examples.explanation: GPS gives your position (coordinates) relative to Earth's reference frame. Updates constantly as you move.
Road distance (actual path) vs straight-line displacement. Seattle to Portland: road distance ≈ 280 km, straight-line ≈ 230 km.
Daily commute: home → work → home. Total distance = 2 × one-way distance. Net displacement = 0.

categories.description: Track and field use position and displacement.

examples.explanation: Straight line race. Distance = displacement magnitude = 100 m.
One lap around oval. Distance = 400 m, displacement = 0 (return to start).
26.2 miles distance. Displacement typically much less (often point-to-point, not round trip).
Walk all through store (large distance), exit near entrance (small displacement).
Up 5 floors, down 3 floors. Distance = 8 floors. Displacement = +2 floors (net upward).

summary: Position is the location of an object relative to a chosen origin, specified by coordinates in a reference frame. In one-dimensional motion, position $x$ is a single coordinate with sign indicating direction from origin. Position can be positive, negative, or zero. Displacement is the change in position: $\Delta x = x_f - x_i$ (final position minus initial position). Displacement is a vector—it has magnitude and direction indicated by + or - sign. Displacement depends only on initial and final positions, not on the path taken. Distance is the total length of the path actually traveled—a scalar quantity that is always positive or zero. Distance accounts for every part of the journey, regardless of direction. Key distinctions: Position tells where an object is. Displacement tells the straight-line change from start to finish. Distance tells total path length traveled. Distance equals |displacement| only for straight-line motion without reversal. In all other cases (curves, back-and-forth, round trips), distance > |displacement|. For round trips returning to start: displacement = 0, but distance = total journey length. Understanding all three quantities provides complete description of where objects are and how they've moved. Position and displacement use reference frames with sign conventions; distance is always positive and doesn't require direction specification.
